BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are to some extent precarious.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The extensive wind slabs of the last few days are prone to triggering in all aspects above the tree line, this also applies on very steep slopes in areas close to the tree line. In addition further wind slabs will form adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as the day progresses. They can be released by a single winter sport participant and reach large size in isolated cases. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
Weak layers in the lower part of the snowpack can still be released in very isolated cases on steep, rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. These avalanche prone locations are very rare but are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye.

On extremely steep sunny slopes medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected. In the event of solar radiation this applies.
In addition a substantial danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep grassy slopes in all aspects in particular below approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The storm force wind has transported the new snow significantly. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs will form at elevated altitudes. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Isolated avalanche prone weak layers exist in the bottom section of the old snowpack on steep, rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Reports filed by observers and avalanches triggered by explosives confirm a sometimes precarious avalanche situation.

The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. The snowpack will be moist below approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming there will be a decrease in the danger of dry avalanches within the current danger level. The wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes. Gliding avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming. As a consequence of solar radiation more loose snow avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects: The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly. As a consequence of a strong to storm force wind, sometimes deep wind slabs formed in the last few days in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
In particular at a distance from ridgelines places that are protected from the wind: More recent wind slabs are easy to recognise but can in some cases be released easily. Caution is to be exercised on steep slopes in particular between approximately 2300 and 2800 m. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
The weather will be mild. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain, and at the base of rock walls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. More recent wind slabs are to be found especially areas not adjacent to ridgelines.
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase a little at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are prone to triggering above the tree line. They can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, as well as in gullies and bowls. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Avalanches can in very isolated cases penetrate deep layers and reach large size, especially on steep, rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses. In addition a certain danger of gliding avalanches exists, especially on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and up to 50 cm in some localities, has fallen since Thursday above approximately 1500 m. The storm force wind has transported the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

Low and intermediate altitudes: The snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in danger of dry avalanches. Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. Gliding avalanches require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In particular in the regions of the north exposed to the foehn wind wind slabs formed.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant. Wind slabs are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. In particular on very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be released in the various wind slab layers and reach large size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. The wind was strong. The soft wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in particular on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects, especially in areas close to the tree line and above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The fresh wind slabs can especially at their margins be released very easily. Avalanches can also penetrate deep layers and reach medium size.
The conditions are precarious for backcountry touring and other off-piste activities outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the regions of the north exposed to the foehn wind 15 to 30 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 2000 m. The violent wind has transported some snow. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at elevated altitudes.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the large wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to gradual consolidation of the snowpack. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Above approximately 2500 m snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to significant settling of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 1800 m. In particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized slab avalanches are possible. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. As a consequence of new snow and wind from northerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects: The strong wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly.
In particular transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind: Fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released easily, especially on very steep shady slopes.
The weather will be mild. Mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain, and at the base of rock walls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. More recent wind slabs are to be found especially areas not adjacent to ridgelines. In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface during the last few days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist avalanches being released will increase a little at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs can be released easily in some places, especially on steep shady slopes in areas close to the tree line, as well as above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches is a little higher. Avalanches can reach medium size.

On rocky sunny slopes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Thursday above approximately 1500 m. The storm force wind has transported the new snow. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on near-ridge shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The storm force wind has transported the fresh and old snow significantly. The fresh and older wind slabs represent the main danger. In particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain medium-sized slab avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases. Between approximately 2400 and 3000 m the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of the wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to consolidation of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released easily. or in isolated cases naturally,, especially on steep shady slopes in areas close to the tree line, as well as above the tree line. They can especially at their margins be released very easily. Caution is to be exercised in particular at the base of rock walls, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. Avalanches can reach medium size.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.
Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Slight increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation, in particular on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry and freeriding conditions are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and can be released by large loads at their margins in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase on steep sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are easy to recognise and unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The surface of the snowpack will soften during the day. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Hardly any small avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming. Very isolated avalanche prone locations are to be found at high altitude and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs are to be found in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. They are very small. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to softening of the old snowpack. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint. There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
